title: Seamless setup of a reproducible research project
text: scientists start working large-scale data analysis, typically learn field-specific skills (e.g., analyzing sequencing data bioinformaticians, modelling mathematicians, etc.), project management skills largely overlooked. years, culminated now call “reproducibility crisis”: researchers document analyses /consistent way organizing data, code, products project. goal tidyproj provide researchers simple framework set standard directory structure can () used across projects. way, researchers can easily switch across projects without ask “save table paper?” “code used create figure?”. establish reproducible consistent project structure tidyproj, help people want reproduce work, also future self, can go back project several months easily find ’re looking .

title: Seamless setup of a reproducible research project
text: can install tidyproj GitHub following code:
code: if(!requireNamespace('remotes', quietly = TRUE))   install.packages('remotes')  remotes::install_github("almeidasilvaf/tidyproj") # Load package after installation library(tidyproj)

title: Seamless setup of a reproducible research project
text: create tidyproj’s standard project structure, need one function: create_project_tree(). default, function assumes already created R Project (.Rproj file), create project structure path returned ::(). However, can specify another root directory. , create project structure using temporary directory root directory. function create_project_tree() creates 3 directories (data, code, products), well README.md file. sections , find mean.
code: # Create project structure in a temporary directory rootdir <- file.path(tempdir(), "example_project") rootdir #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpfzDGt8/example_project"  create_project_tree(rootdir) #> /tmp/RtmpfzDGt8/example_project #> ├── README.md #> ├── code #> │   ├── 01_first_analysis.Rmd #> │   └── 02_second_analysis.Rmd #> ├── data #> │   └── DATA_DESCRIPTION.Rmd #> └── products #>     ├── figs #>     ├── plots #>     ├── result_files #>     └── tables

title: Seamless setup of a reproducible research project
text: code/ directory contains .Rmd files describe analyses (code text). file already prepopulated fields present documents. Let’s take look one . mandatory sections .Rmd file include: Overview: section, briefly describe document, listing objectives want achieve scientific questions trying address. Analysis [n]: sections write code data analyses. Always try use section objective described Overview. Thus, want answer 4 questions specific .Rmd file, list 4 questions Overview write separate Analysis section question. Besides, make sure include code chunks, also text describing analysis summarizing observed. 100% sure help write paper, already summary findings. sense, write parts paper analyses, super helpful. Session information: section contains code chunk display information everything used R session, including OS, R version, packages loaded, packages used indirectly, etc. Note code chunks evaluated default (except session information code). real-world scientific projects contain heavy analyses code chunks take long time run. important evaluated code documentations, always possible. end day, ’s way better documented code evaluated documentation . However, .Rmd file describes analyses take long time run, can () set eval = TRUE code chunk options.
code: # Path to .Rmd file 01_first_analysis.Rmd rmd1 <- file.path(rootdir, "code", "01_first_analysis.Rmd")  # Print content of the file cat(readLines(rmd1), sep = "\n") #> --- #> title: "Document name" #> author: "Your Name" #> date: "`r Sys.Date()`" #> output: BiocStyle::pdf_document #> --- #>  #> ```{r setup, include=FALSE} #> knitr::opts_chunk$set( #>     echo = TRUE, #>     warning = FALSE,  #>     message = FALSE, #>     eval = FALSE, #>     tidy.opts = list(width.cutoff = 60), #>     tidy = TRUE #> ) #> ``` #>  #> ```{r here} #> set.seed(123) # for reproducibility #>  #> # Load required packages #> library(here) #> ``` #>  #> # Overview #>  #> Here, we will describe the code to: #>  #> 1. Goal 1 #> 2. Goal 2 #> 3. Goal 3 #>  #>  #> # Analysis 1 #>  #> ```{r} #> data(airquality) #> head(airquality) #> ``` #>  #> # Analysis 2 #>  #> ```{r} #> data(airquality) #> head(airquality) #> ``` #>  #> # Session information {.unnumbered} #>  #> This document was created under the following conditions: #>  #> ```{r sessioninfo, eval = TRUE} #> sessioninfo::session_info() #> ```

title: Seamless setup of a reproducible research project
text: directory must contain products obtain analyses, classified different categories: plots: plots create stored. Plots can stored image files (e.g., .png, .pdf, .svg, etc) .rda files used working ggplot objects. strongly recommend saving plots .rda files, can manipulate later without rerun code create . particularly useful want modify aesthetics ggplot objects (e.g., color, size, etc) combine multiple ggplots multiple panels make complex figure. figs: final figures (elegant complex ones go paper) stored. example, can store PDF figure created combining several ggplot objects contained plots subdirectory. tables: tables summary statistics stored. Avoid saving tables .xlsx (Excel) files. want create .xlsx file multiple tabs represents whole set Supplementary Tables, can , keep original tables used tab .csv/.tsv/.txt files. result_files: files important results stored. can .rda files R objects (e.g., DESeq object differential gene expression analysis, lm object model fit, etc.) /files stored tabular format tables subdirectory (e.g., .nwk files representing phylogenies, software output specific format, etc).
